key_points: Anthony Antonio, charged with five federal crimes related to the Capitol riot, said he believed 'America was being robbed of a president' due to false claims.
Antonio admitted to participating in the insurrection influenced by misinformation from Fox News and former President Donald Trump.
He acknowledges Joe Biden as the legitimate President but felt deceived by the false information about the 2020 election.
His lawyer, Joseph Hurley, introduced the term 'Foxitis' to describe Antonio's condition after losing his job and consuming Fox News content.
Many Capitol riot defendants have unsuccessfully blamed Trump for their actions; judges are concerned about the role of right-wing media.
Antonio expressed regret for his participation in the riot and acknowledged his mistake in not aiding DC Metropolitan Police Officer Michael Fanone.
Court documents reveal Antonio's actions during the riot, including shouting at police, pouring water on an officer, and entering the Capitol.
The Justice Department has charged hundreds from 43 states and Washington, DC, in the massive federal inquiry into the insurrection.
Federal prosecutors expect to charge at least 500 people in relation to the January 6 insurrection.
He realized he had been misled a few days after the insurrection but takes full responsibility for his actions.
